document.docAuthor: Delvare, G., Escolà, A. Ribes, Stojanova, A. M., Benoit, L., Lecomte, J. & Askew, R. R.
document.masterDocTitle: Exploring insect biodiversity: the parasitic Hymenoptera, chiefly Chalcidoidea, associated with seeds of asphodels (Xanthorrhoeaceae), with the description of nine new species belonging to Eurytomidae and Torymidae

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Exploring insect biodiversity: the parasitic Hymenoptera, chiefly Chalcidoidea, associated with seeds of asphodels (Xanthorrhoeaceae), with the description of nine new species belonging to Eurytomidae and Torymidae

(2015) Availability of eleven species names of Eupelmus (Hymenoptera, Eupelmidae) proposed in Al khatib et al. (2014). ZooKeys, 505, 137 - 145. https: // doi. org / 10.3897 / zookeys. 505.9021

Biology . Trophic relationships .
Eupelmus confusus
belongs to the
urozonus
species group, a complex of closely allied and sibling species that are commonly reared from plant galls, especially those of Cynipidae ( Hymenoptera ), Tephritidae and Cecidomyiidae ( Diptera ), but they also attack cocooned Lepidoptera and their primary parasitoids, as well as other host groups ( Gibson 2011 ;
Al khatib et al. 2014
, 2016 ). The host species mentioned by
Al khatib et al . (2014)
Bruchophagus
sp. [=
B. insulare
described here] in
A. ramosus
( Fig. 42 ),
Macrolabis
[=
Lasioptera
] laserpitii Rubsaamen, 1917 and
Asphondylia
sp. ( Cecidomyiidae ),
Myopites stylata (Fabricius, 1794)
and
Bactrocera oleae Gmelin, 1790
( Tephritidae ),
Andricus kollari (Hartig, 1843)
,
Biorhiza pallida (Olivier, 1791)
,
Diplolepis rosae
,
D. kuriphilus
and
Timaspis phoenixopodos Mayr, 1882
( Cynipidae ).

In the course of opening seeds in a sample of
A. albus albus
from France (Vienne), dead males of
E. confusus
were found within two seeds ( Fig. 39 ). In one seed two males, one still partly in its pupal case, were with the remains of an adult female
Pteromalus tethys
(below) on which they had evidently developed as either secondary or tertiary parasitoids of
B. abscedus
. Another male
E. confusus
appeared to be with the remains of a larva of Tortricidae ( Lepidoptera ), probably
Cochylis epilinana Duponchel, 1842
.

Phenology . In our study a male emerged after overwintering from
A. albus albus
fruits collected in France , 8 ♀ 2 ♂ emerged in the first year from fruits of
A. cerasiferus
from France , as did 4 ♀ 3 ♂ from fruits of
A. ramosus
collected in Sicilia, and 2 ♀ were reared from fruits of
Asphodelus
sp. from Turkey and a single male, most probably of
E. confusus
, emerged from an
A. fistulosus
seed capsule from Spain (Lleida, Alfes, collected 21.vi.2011 , A. Ribes).
